snippet: Markus Rehm, a world-class German long jumper who uses a prosthetic blade, now finds himself in the same arena of confusion as Oscar Pistorius over how the line is drawn between able-bodied and disabled athletes.
abstract: Markus Rehm, world-class German long jumper who uses a prosthetic blade in competition, faces renewed controversy on how to draw the line between able-bodied and disabled athletes; Rehm was denied position on roster for the European Championships despite winning national competition, honor historically all but guaranteed to national champion; case echoes concerns raised in 2007 when double-amputee Oscar Pistorius battled to compete in the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Markus Rehm, a world-class German long jumper who uses a prosthetic blade, now finds himself in the same arena of confusion as Oscar Pistorius over how the line is drawn between able-bodied and disabled athletes.

headline.main: For Jumper, Renewed Debate Over Athletic Versus Prosthetic
headline.print_headline: For Jumper, Renewed Debate Over Athletic Versus Prosthetic
